blog.name: captainfjord
blog.title: STEP INTO THE VOID

tags: i am in my feelings ya’ll
summary: I would have never thought in all my years on this earth that Thursday’s would mean so much to me after stumbling upon a bunch...
body:
I would have never thought in all my years on this earth that Thursday’s would mean so much to me after stumbling upon a bunch of nerdy voice actors playing dungeons and dragons. It became something to look forward too each week, some weeks it was the only thing that kept me going. Counting down the days until the next episode. Critical Role has become a major part of my life and has in many ways guiding me through the hardest of times. Through my health complications and losing loved ones to even losing someone i once thought to be the love of my life. This game helped me laugh and smile when things i used to love doing didn’t, it got me to write again something i was passionate about for years, it brought me close to someone i admired and we quickly became best friends and now i can’t picture my life without her. This game is special to me and probably a lot of others and i’m just glad i found it when i did.

I’m also really glad these nerds decided to share their game with us all those years ago. 💜💜💜

tags: but it felt like the only one she ever really connected with was molly
summary: I can’t help but feel like when Yasha came back and is introduced to Cad that internally she was a great deal more upset. Like,...
body:
I can’t help but feel like when Yasha came back and is introduced to Cad that internally she was a great deal more upset.

Like, “…really? You guys couldn’t be bothered to protect or bring back my best friend…but you have…this?? REALLY??”

but of course it’s Yasha so on the outside she’s just, “…oh…”

but you gatta know there’s gatta be some quiet resentment buried down deep.

tags: also at lv 9 you can run on water because monks
can't wait for beau to get even more badass
summary: What’s cool about the silly “Beau tries to climb wizard tower” hijinks from last week is that later on it could be interpreted...
body:
What’s cool about the silly “Beau tries to climb wizard tower” hijinks from last week is that later on it could be interpreted as RP for the future. 

When monks reach level 9 they can use their movement to just get up vertical surfaces without falling. So level 9 Beau could get up to that 20ft balcony easy, and this attempt seems like Beau practicing to do that in the future!

Aspiring Professor
...Nocturnal Creature...

summary:
(Huge spoilers to Campaing 1, Campaign 2 ep. 33-34)
As I work on the massive undertaking of rewriting the entire Vox Machina...
body:
Morning Thoughts on Matt’s Mercer: Master of the Long Con

(Huge spoilers to Campaing 1, Campaign 2 ep. 33-34)

As I work on the massive undertaking of rewriting the entire Vox Machina saga in a modern/cyberpunk universe, I’ve found myself both obligated and compelled go re-watch episodes from C1 to get the order of events straight.

During this process, I’ve come to realize that the intricate storytelling that Matt commits himself to is something that critters may not pick up on get during a first viewing. The level of foreshadowing that he includes in the work is a craft to be adimred, and yet it’s something unlike any other form of media: No show has the luxury of having so many hours of runtime, so Matt can really go for the long con. However, simultaneously, no show has the level of flexibly and unpredictability as Critical Role, because so much of the storytelling is based on the players.

Unlike a scripted show, Matt can’t simply say “and you will come back here and discover THIS THING I’ve been planning for years.” So inserting these little hints to future events that may not even happen is a huge risk and could prove it’s self to be time wasted. He will plan plot twists literally years ahead of time, to then surprize of both the players and the viewers…

Spoilers begin here:

Many new critters have got to experience their first Mercer twist with the reveal that the Gentleman may be Jester’s father, an NPC that they have known for most of the series so far.

This shook the new fan base and had them realize just how long Matt tends to plan these circumstances. But this isn’t the first time Matt has done something like this, nor is it the most impressive.

In C1, Matt had a few plot twists shake the fan base at the core, particularly when it comes to recurring villains.

Although we as viewers were unaware of it at the time, the players – who’d been playing for ar least a couple of years before the stream started – were socked to see the Chroma conclave rise up after Vox Machina accidentally killed one of the 5 a few years prior, virtually unaware that they were part of a larger collective. However, they did recieve hints, particular when they discovered “orbs” that were later reveals to be communication devices for the dragons.

I first came to realize just how early on the events of the Chroma conclave were set into motion during the writing of the pre-steam content in my Chaos Theory AU. I realized that if I was going to make the Chroma Conclave as significant and shocking as in the show, I’d have to hint their existance well beforehand, just as Matt had.

We saw this happen again with Hotis, the Rakshasa, who foreshadowed his return upon his defeat in episode 24, only to return in episode 57 in a shocking reveal.

Dr Anna Ripley was another example: upon fleeing Vox Machina’s grasp during the Briarwood arc in the ep 30s (or something) we got hints that she was still roaming Exandria until the reveal in the 60s that she was indeed looking for the Vestiges of Divergence, which of course Vox Machina wanted. Not only that, but we discovered that she had recruited Kynan, an NPC that Vax insulted/inspired literally 40 episodes prior.

But one of the the most shocking reveals was when we discovered that Lady Briarwood, who’d been killed and her body disolved in a vat of acid and left for dead in the 30s, was still alive in episode 100. Furthermore, we got hints to the existance of Vecna during that episode as well, a villain that we would not exprience till the very end of the show.

This is a testament to how much Matt thinks about his stories ahead of time. He would never be able to do this if he didn’t already have everything planned in his head, which shows that he isn’t simply pulling new plot points out of the blue like so many long running show so: he’s planning this literally years ahead of time.

This has proven to be both a delight and a struggle when writing a modern adaptation. Much like Matt, I’ve been forced to plan certain events well ahead of time, but with no magic to pull me out of plot holes.

Not only did I need to know that General Kreig was part of a larger conspiracy, but I had to drop hints during the “demon” attack at the Cloudtop. I had to make Eskil Ryndarian a slightly more established NPC, since he shows up later on as someone who knows of Vecna. I had to think about Master Qual, and Abjurist Noja, all significant pre-steam NPCs that showed up later in the show. I even gave Trista the Hag more coverage because I worried she’d come up later.

But there are so many othwr things I’ve also had to consider: Not only do I need to know what the Briarwoods are plotting, but I need to know how that relates to “vecna”. I need to know how go translate Hotis into a villain and how he will come back. I need to plot the movements of Anna Ripley. Fortunately, I have the luxury of working on a my fic well after the reveal of these twists, but had I started writing maybe a year earlier, I could have royally written myself in a corner.

I had orginally plotted for the Briarwoods to both perish during the Briarwood Arc in my modern au. However, when their survival was revealed in episode 100, I realized doing so would have then forced me to pull a Moriarty in the modern Sherlock series with some pre-recorded video shit, given that there is no magic in the setting I’m writing.

It just goes to show how much planning Matt dedicates himself to, and how much he has to remember. To this day, I still find miself bighting my nails worrying whether something will be revealed that I cannot retroactively change: what if Artagan reveals himself to be the Traveler? I’d originally planned Garmilee to be nothing more than a homeless scientist…

What if NPCs that I did not deem important show up all of a sudden (like the captain of she ship we just saw in episode 34 of C2) become a pivotal character? It’s also why I can’t start thinking about the M9 in my Chaos Theory setting yet. I don’t know what Matt plans to do with the Traveler, the dodecahedron, Mollymauk/Lucien… What if Molly becomes the next villain? What if the dodecahedron steals someone’s soul? Those future events dictate how I translate past events into a modern setting if I want to stay compliant to the canon, which is why I simply can’t start writing M9 content yet.

Nedless to say, writing something of this magnitude is not easy when you’re working off of Matt’s brain, but it’s definitely fun, and I can’t wait to see what plot twists he reveals next, because we KNOW he’s going to do it again.

Sincerely,

The Scarecrowlover

________________________

Read “Chaos Theory: A Comprehensive Modern Re-imagining of the Vox Machina Saga” on AO3: Link

Rated “E” for graphic violence.

I first came to realize just how early on the events of the Chroma conclave were set into motion during the writing of the pre-steam content in my Chaos Theory AU. I realized that if I was going to make the Chroma Conclave as significant and shocking as in the show, I’d have to hint their existance well beforehand, just as Matt had.

We saw this happen again with Hotis, the Rakshasa, who foreshadowed his return upon his defeat in episode 24, only to return in episode 57 in a shocking reveal.

Dr Anna Ripley was another example: upon fleeing Vox Machina’s grasp during the Briarwood arc in the ep 30s (or something) we got hints that she was still roaming Exandria until the reveal in the 60s that she was indeed looking for the Vestiges of Divergence, which of course Vox Machina wanted. Not only that, but we discovered that she had recruited Kynan, an NPC that Vax insulted/inspired literally 40 episodes prior.

But one of the the most shocking reveals was when we discovered that Lady Briarwood, who’d been killed and her body disolved in a vat of acid and left for dead in the 30s, was still alive in episode 100. Furthermore, we got hints to the existance of Vecna during that episode as well, a villain that we would not exprience till the very end of the show.

This is a testament to how much Matt thinks about his stories ahead of time. He would never be able to do this if he didn’t already have everything planned in his head, which shows that he isn’t simply pulling new plot points out of the blue like so many long running show so: he’s planning this literally years ahead of time.

This has proven to be both a delight and a struggle when writing a modern adaptation. Much like Matt, I’ve been forced to plan certain events well ahead of time, but with no magic to pull me out of plot holes.

Not only did I need to know that General Kreig was part of a larger conspiracy, but I had to drop hints during the “demon” attack at the Cloudtop. I had to make Eskil Ryndarian a slightly more established NPC, since he shows up later on as someone who knows of Vecna. I had to think about Master Qual, and Abjurist Noja, all significant pre-steam NPCs that showed up later in the show. I even gave Trista the Hag more coverage because I worried she’d come up later.

But there are so many othwr things I’ve also had to consider: Not only do I need to know what the Briarwoods are plotting, but I need to know how that relates to “vecna”. I need to know how go translate Hotis into a villain and how he will come back. I need to plot the movements of Anna Ripley. Fortunately, I have the luxury of working on a my fic well after the reveal of these twists, but had I started writing maybe a year earlier, I could have royally written myself in a corner.

I had orginally plotted for the Briarwoods to both perish during the Briarwood Arc in my modern au. However, when their survival was revealed in episode 100, I realized doing so would have then forced me to pull a Moriarty in the modern Sherlock series with some pre-recorded video shit, given that there is no magic in the setting I’m writing.

It just goes to show how much planning Matt dedicates himself to, and how much he has to remember. To this day, I still find miself bighting my nails worrying whether something will be revealed that I cannot retroactively change: what if Artagan reveals himself to be the Traveler? I’d originally planned Garmilee to be nothing more than a homeless scientist…

What if NPCs that I did not deem important show up all of a sudden (like the captain of she ship we just saw in episode 34 of C2) become a pivotal character? It’s also why I can’t start thinking about the M9 in my Chaos Theory setting yet. I don’t know what Matt plans to do with the Traveler, the dodecahedron, Mollymauk/Lucien… What if Molly becomes the next villain? What if the dodecahedron steals someone’s soul? Those future events dictate how I translate past events into a modern setting if I want to stay compliant to the canon, which is why I simply can’t start writing M9 content yet.

Nedless to say, writing something of this magnitude is not easy when you’re working off of Matt’s brain, but it’s definitely fun, and I can’t wait to see what plot twists he reveals next, because we KNOW he’s going to do it again.

Sincerely,

The Scarecrowlover

________________________

Read “Chaos Theory: A Comprehensive Modern Re-imagining of the Vox Machina Saga” on AO3: Link

Rated “E” for graphic violence.

trail.content_raw:
Morning Thoughts on Matt’s Mercer: Master of the Long Con

(Huge spoilers to Campaing 1, Campaign 2 ep. 33-34)

As I work on the massive undertaking of rewriting the entire Vox Machina saga in a modern/cyberpunk universe, I’ve found myself both obligated and compelled go re-watch episodes from C1 to get the order of events straight.

During this process, I’ve come to realize that the intricate storytelling that Matt commits himself to is something that critters may not pick up on get during a first viewing. The level of foreshadowing that he includes in the work is a craft to be adimred, and yet it’s something unlike any other form of media: No show has the luxury of having so many hours of runtime, so Matt can really go for the long con. However, simultaneously, no show has the level of flexibly and unpredictability as Critical Role, because so much of the storytelling is based on the players.

Unlike a scripted show, Matt can’t simply say “and you will come back here and discover THIS THING I’ve been planning for years.” So inserting these little hints to future events that may not even happen is a huge risk and could prove it’s self to be time wasted. He will plan plot twists literally years ahead of time, to then surprize of both the players and the viewers…

Spoilers begin here:

Many new critters have got to experience their first Mercer twist with the reveal that the Gentleman may be Jester’s father, an NPC that they have known for most of the series so far.

This shook the new fan base and had them realize just how long Matt tends to plan these circumstances. But this isn’t the first time Matt has done something like this, nor is it the most impressive.

In C1, Matt had a few plot twists shake the fan base at the core, particularly when it comes to recurring villains.

Although we as viewers were unaware of it at the time, the players – who’d been playing for ar least a couple of years before the stream started – were socked to see the Chroma conclave rise up after Vox Machina accidentally killed one of the 5 a few years prior, virtually unaware that they were part of a larger collective. However, they did recieve hints, particular when they discovered “orbs” that were later reveals to be communication devices for the dragons.

I first came to realize just how early on the events of the Chroma conclave were set into motion during the writing of the pre-steam content in my Chaos Theory AU. I realized that if I was going to make the Chroma Conclave as significant and shocking as in the show, I’d have to hint their existance well beforehand, just as Matt had.

We saw this happen again with Hotis, the Rakshasa, who foreshadowed his return upon his defeat in episode 24, only to return in episode 57 in a shocking reveal.

Dr Anna Ripley was another example: upon fleeing Vox Machina’s grasp during the Briarwood arc in the ep 30s (or something) we got hints that she was still roaming Exandria until the reveal in the 60s that she was indeed looking for the Vestiges of Divergence, which of course Vox Machina wanted. Not only that, but we discovered that she had recruited Kynan, an NPC that Vax insulted/inspired literally 40 episodes prior.

But one of the the most shocking reveals was when we discovered that Lady Briarwood, who’d been killed and her body disolved in a vat of acid and left for dead in the 30s, was still alive in episode 100. Furthermore, we got hints to the existance of Vecna during that episode as well, a villain that we would not exprience till the very end of the show.

This is a testament to how much Matt thinks about his stories ahead of time. He would never be able to do this if he didn’t already have everything planned in his head, which shows that he isn’t simply pulling new plot points out of the blue like so many long running show so: he’s planning this literally years ahead of time.

This has proven to be both a delight and a struggle when writing a modern adaptation. Much like Matt, I’ve been forced to plan certain events well ahead of time, but with no magic to pull me out of plot holes.

Not only did I need to know that General Kreig was part of a larger conspiracy, but I had to drop hints during the “demon” attack at the Cloudtop. I had to make Eskil Ryndarian a slightly more established NPC, since he shows up later on as someone who knows of Vecna. I had to think about Master Qual, and Abjurist Noja, all significant pre-steam NPCs that showed up later in the show. I even gave Trista the Hag more coverage because I worried she’d come up later.

But there are so many othwr things I’ve also had to consider: Not only do I need to know what the Briarwoods are plotting, but I need to know how that relates to “vecna”. I need to know how go translate Hotis into a villain and how he will come back. I need to plot the movements of Anna Ripley. Fortunately, I have the luxury of working on a my fic well after the reveal of these twists, but had I started writing maybe a year earlier, I could have royally written myself in a corner.

I had orginally plotted for the Briarwoods to both perish during the Briarwood Arc in my modern au. However, when their survival was revealed in episode 100, I realized doing so would have then forced me to pull a Moriarty in the modern Sherlock series with some pre-recorded video shit, given that there is no magic in the setting I’m writing.

It just goes to show how much planning Matt dedicates himself to, and how much he has to remember. To this day, I still find miself bighting my nails worrying whether something will be revealed that I cannot retroactively change: what if Artagan reveals himself to be the Traveler? I’d originally planned Garmilee to be nothing more than a homeless scientist…

What if NPCs that I did not deem important show up all of a sudden (like the captain of she ship we just saw in episode 34 of C2) become a pivotal character? It’s also why I can’t start thinking about the M9 in my Chaos Theory setting yet. I don’t know what Matt plans to do with the Traveler, the dodecahedron, Mollymauk/Lucien… What if Molly becomes the next villain? What if the dodecahedron steals someone’s soul? Those future events dictate how I translate past events into a modern setting if I want to stay compliant to the canon, which is why I simply can’t start writing M9 content yet.

Nedless to say, writing something of this magnitude is not easy when you’re working off of Matt’s brain, but it’s definitely fun, and I can’t wait to see what plot twists he reveals next, because we KNOW he’s going to do it again.

Sincerely,

The Scarecrowlover

________________________

summary: Seven, Eight, Nein! - Chapter 1 - Midnigtartist - Critical Role (Web Series) [Archive of Our Own]
title: Seven, Eight, Nein! - Chapter 1 - Midnigtartist - Critical Role (Web Series) [Archive of Our Own]

description:
I’ve been talking about this au forever so I figured I might as well write it already.
A modern with magic college au that loosely follows some sort if plot (read: a bunch of headcannons, college cliches, and shippy bullshit in an unnecessarily complicated trench coat)

Chapter two:  I promised a bunch of dumb troopes in a trenchcoat so get ready for three meet-cutes and a night at the theater.
